Types of Pronouns

Let's learn about Types of Pronouns and their examples.

Pronouns are of following types:

Pronouns can be classified into different types based on their functions. Given below are the various types of pronouns. Go through the examples carefully to have a clear understanding of each type of pronoun and its function.

1. Relative Pronouns
2. Possessive Pronouns
3. Reflexive Pronouns
4. Demonstrative Pronouns
5. Interrogative Pronouns
6. Indefinite Pronouns
7. Personal Pronouns

1. Relative Pronouns

A relative pronoun is a word that is used to connect an independent clause to a relative clause. Relative pronouns are meant to provide more information about the subject (noun or pronoun) it relates to. These relative pronouns function exactly like adjectives, and so the clauses they form can also be called adjective clauses.

Examples of Relative Pronouns

Who – Refers to a person (the noun/pronoun/subject which does the action).
Whom – Refers to the object (the noun or pronoun that receives the action).
Whose – Used to show possession of something or someone.
That – Used in a defining clause that refers to a person, animal or thing.

Sheela, who is a teacher, also works as a social worker.



The car that was stolen last month was found in a river.
Susan is the girl whom I was talking about.



The boy, whose sister is a renowned orator, is an orator himself.
The girl, who saved the little boy, was appreciated by everyone.


2. Possessive Pronouns

Possessive pronouns are pronouns that are used to show your possession or ownership of someone or something. They indicate that they belong to that particular person and no one else. Possessive pronouns can be used instead of a noun phrase to avoid any repetition.

Examples of Possessive Pronouns

Bobby is a brother of mine.
Is this book yours?

That little girl is my daughter, and this one is hers.

The cake Diana baked last week is not as good as yours.

It was not your fault but theirs.

3. Reflexive Pronouns

The word ‘reflexive’ means something that is directed towards the self. A reflexive pronoun, therefore, is expected to do the same thing. It reflects back on the pronoun. It takes the place of a subject pronoun and an object pronoun in a sentence.

Examples of Reflexive Pronouns

They looked at themselves.
I learnt to drive a car by myself.



It is a fact that you know yourself and what is going on around you.



Teena and Tyson have been preparing themselves for the entire semester.
Rahul was so tired of following diets that he decided to give himself a cheat day.

4. Demonstrative Pronouns

Everyone might be familiar with the word ‘demo’. The word demo is most commonly used as an acronym for demonstration. Demonstration means to indicate, identify, point out, exhibit or explain something to someone. A demonstrative pronoun is used to do the same thing. It demonstrates or represents the nouns that act as the subject or object in a sentence.

Examples of Demonstrative Pronouns

This is my cousin.
That car is expensive.

These flowers smell nice.
Those birds are flying towards south.



5. Interrogative Pronouns

An interrogative pronoun, like the name suggests, is used to ask questions. It refers to something or someone. What, which, who, whom and whose are the five interrogative pronouns in the English language.

Examples of Interrogative Pronouns

Who is your best friend?
By whom he was caught?



Which of the boys is tallest?
Whose books are these?



6. Indefinite Pronouns

An indefinite pronoun is a pronoun that is used to substitute nouns that are not specific. Indefinite pronouns can be used in the singular and plural forms.

Examples of Indefinite Pronouns

Can someone/ somebody tell me what is happening here?
Everyone/ Everybody liked the movie.



7. Personal Pronouns

A personal pronoun is a short word we use as a simple substitute for the proper name of a person. Each of the English personal pronouns shows us the grammatical person, gender, number, and case of the noun it replaces. I, you, he, she, it, we, they, me, him, her, us, and them are all personal pronouns.



Examples of Personal Pronouns

Personal pronouns can be broadly classified into three main categories –
(i) First person pronoun
(ii) Second person pronoun
(iii) Third person pronoun
These pronouns are used in the nominative and objective format and in the singular and plural forms.



First person pronoun


Singular


Plural



Second person pronoun


Singular


Plural



Third person pronoun


Singular
